Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Medium: Provisioning and Harnessing Energy Storage for Datacenter Demand Response

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Power consumption of datacenters poses economic, societal and environmental concerns. A large datacenter spends millions of dollars in yearly operational expenditures (op-ex) paying its electricity bills, and in provisioning the power delivery network, to accommodate the peak power draw, even if this draw is rarely sustained. Re-shaping the power draw temporally (over time) and spatially (across regions of the datacenter, or even across datacenters), broadly referred to as Demand Response (DR), is a common technique to reduce cap-ex and op-ex costs. Until now, datacenter DR has primarily used computing knobs -- consolidation, scheduling, migration, and power state modulation -- to manage the power draw.

This project will investigate a novel set of complementary techniques leveraging Energy Storage Devices (ESDs) in the datacenter for DR. The project will explore specific issues related to provisioning -- type, capacity and location -- ESDs in the datacenter power hierarchy. It will also develop control techniques for sourcing from these devices, and coupling their usage with current computing DR techniques, all the while optimizing for performance, cost, availability and ESD health related criteria. This research will have a direct impact on datacenter power cost reduction and the ability to source renewable energy. The platforms, models and power traces from this work can be useful to further ESD research in datacenters. This project will also enhance interdisciplinary curriculum in the related areas, and lead to new undergraduate honor's thesis projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Power consumption of datacenters poses serious cost, scalability, and environmental concerns. From an operational point of view, the cost of powering the nation's datacenters is expected to exceed $15 billion in the next few years. Even from a single datacenter's viewpoint, power-related costs constitute nearly 60% of the total amortized cost of a datacenter. This cost goes into not just paying the monthly electricity bills (op-ex), but also provisioning the power infrastructures (cap-ex). This project studied several issues related to reducing both the consumption and power related costs through the use of Energy Storage technologies in the datacenter.

Energy storage has the potential of re-shaping the power demand of the datacenter by temporarily boosting supply when needed, and storing energy when there is slack. This allows a datacenter to utilize energy storage devices for a multitude of uses in existing datacenters such as for power outages, peak shaving, etc. and emerging datacenters which coordinates with smart grids for power regulation, renewable integration, etc. 

Major research outcomes: Our research activities have facilitated the development of models, policies and valuable insights into effective power/energy provisioning and management in large-scale data centers. Our findings help datacenter operators to optimize their power and energy infrastructure design and operation. Major outcomes include (i) the use of energy-storage enabled virtualized power infrastructure to achieve cost and performance benefits, (ii) dual-purposing existing energy storage devices originally provisioned for backup power to participate in demand-response without significantly impacting battery health and power availability (iii) policies to manage battery degradation and facilitate online learning of battery health.

Moreover, our research has led to the development of models and frameworks related to energy storage provisioning/operation, battery health degradation as well as datacenter-level capacity planning framework. Using our models, the datacenter operator can navigate the energy storage technology space for cost, performance and environmental benefits when employing batteries for a wide range of emerging power usage scenarios. 

Broader impacts: This funding has enabled graduate student education and training on topics beyond computing, covering holistic datacenter management as well as an in-depth understanding of the area of energy storage. This interdisciplinary work and the research training facilitated by this project should well prepare the student for the next generation workforce. The project generated research publications in top computer science and engineering conferences (HOTPOWER, IISWC, ICSDCS, ASPLOS, ISCA) as well as mechanical engineering conferences and journals (ASME, ACC, JPS).
